central_topic: Mosquito-borne disease surveillance and prevention using a novel, low-cost virus detection method.

subtopics.title: Introduction to Mosquito-Borne Diseases
subtopics.description: Mosquitoes as the deadliest animal, transmitting diseases like malaria and dengue fever. Focus on Ross River virus in Australia.

subtopics.title: Research Question
subtopics.description: Investigating why certain areas have higher rates of mosquito-borne diseases and identifying environmental factors contributing to disease transmission.

children.title: Environmental Factors
children.description: Density of human housing, biodiversity of mammals, and ratio of green space to buildings.

subtopics.title: Novel Virus Detection Method
subtopics.description: Using virus-preserving cards coated in honey to attract mosquitoes and detect viruses.

children.title: Trap Development
children.description: Creating traps from recycled materials (milk cartons, pantyhose, paper clips) for broad-scale virus surveys.

children.title: Cost-Effectiveness
children.description: Traps costing less than $1.00 each and reusable for the whole season.

children.title: Virus Identification
children.description: Detecting Ross River virus, Barmah Forest virus, and Stratford virus (new to South Australia).

subtopics.title: Impact and Applications
subtopics.description: Potential for public health officials to implement the technique for surveillance in other regions and countries, especially in economically impoverished areas.

children.title: Global Health Implications
children.description: Providing a low-budget method for virus surveillance and spatial analysis to help countries with limited resources combat mosquito-borne diseases.
